slides.title: 1.  The essence of mediation is that it is
2.  The nature of the mediation process is that it is

3.  Mediating in the context of Christian faith and practice imposes unique roles and responsibilities on the mediator that are in addition to, and differ from, the roles and responsibilities of "secular" mediators.
4.  Of the following, which are unique roles of the Peace Advocate when serving as a mediator? (Select all that apply.)
5.  Which of the following might a party see as reasons not to negotiate? (Select all that apply.)
6.  Which one of the following lists the four basic points of principled bargaining that help parties effectively engage in integrative negotiation?
7.  By assessing which of the following can a party clarify its desired outcome and better understand how a negotiated agreement can meet its needs? (Select all that apply.)

8.  When it comes to using the various response styles (teaching, supporting, criticizing, probing, clarifying, reflecting) it is important to understand that any of them used 100% of the time results in the speaker perceiving the listener as using that style of response 40% of the time.
9.  For a mediator's questions to be effective they must be intentionally asked.  Which of the following is NOT a reason why mediators ask questions.
10.  Of the following, which one should Peace Advocates NOT consider when determining whether a mediation's outcome was "successful"?
